unnormalised: **The Curious Case of the Endless Degrees: A Millennial’s Guide to Job Hunting (or Avoiding It)**
normalised: The Curious Case of the Endless Degrees: A Millennial’s Guide to Job Hunting (or Avoiding It)

unnormalised: Ah, the glorious pursuit of higher education! In a country obsessed with marks, securing a "good" education is like winning the lottery, but instead of money, you get… more exams! Jokes aside, these days it seems like everyone's got a degree or two, or ten. It's almost as if we’re all competing to see who can collect the most expensive pieces of paper, framed and proudly displayed, silently judging our life choices. Remember that distant relative, "Sharmaji ka ladka?" Well, rumor has it, he's now Dr. Sharmaji ka ladka, Esq., MBA, Ph.D., with a minor in astrophysics. Just kidding… maybe.
normalised: Ah, the glorious pursuit of higher education! In a country obsessed with marks, securing a “good” education is like winning the lottery, but instead of money, you get… more exams! Jokes aside, these days it seems like everyone's got a degree or two, or ten. It's almost as if we’re all competing to see who can collect the most expensive pieces of paper, framed and proudly displayed, silently judging our life choices. Remember that distant relative, “Sharmaji ka ladka?” Well, rumor has it, he's now Doctor Sharmaji ka ladka, E-S-Q, M-B-A, P-H-D, with a minor in astrophysics. Just kidding… maybe.

unnormalised: Let's face it, the modern Indian resume looks like a laundry list of qualifications. You’ve got your standard B.Com, your MBA from IIM-A, and maybe even a cheeky little diploma in digital marketing from some random institute. But are these titles really the golden ticket to success? Or are we just perpetually stuck in student mode, forever chasing the next certification to avoid the existential dread of a 9-to-5? I remember a friend, Rahul, who proudly displayed "Certified Excel Expert" on his LinkedIn profile. Turns out, he only knew how to sum a column of numbers. The audacity!
normalised: Let's face it, the modern Indian resume looks like a laundry list of qualifications. You’ve got your standard B-Com, your M-B-A from I-I-M-A, and maybe even a cheeky little diploma in digital marketing from some random institute. But are these titles really the golden ticket to success? Or are we just perpetually stuck in student mode, forever chasing the next certification to avoid the existential dread of a nine to five? I remember a friend, Rahul, who proudly displayed “Certified Excel Expert” on his LinkedIn profile. Turns out, he only knew how to sum a column of numbers. The audacity!

unnormalised: Then there are the honorary titles bestowed upon us by our loving (read: demanding) parents. "Engineer beta" or "Doctor beti" are uttered with such reverence that you'd think we've personally invented the internet or cured cancer. Never mind that you spend your days debugging WordPress plugins or writing prescriptions for cough syrup. The title is the thing! My neighbour aunty still calls my brother "Engineer sahab", even though he is a stand up comic now.
normalised: Then there are the honorary titles bestowed upon us by our loving (read: demanding) parents. “Engineer beta” or “Doctor beti” are uttered with such reverence that you'd think we've personally invented the internet or cured cancer. Never mind that you spend your days debugging WordPress plugins or writing prescriptions for cough syrup. The title is the thing! My neighbour aunty still calls my brother “Engineer sahab”, even though he is a stand up comic now.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the abbreviations. You spend years deciphering what a "PGDM" or an "M.Tech" actually means, only to realize it's just a fancy way of saying "I spent a lot of money on a piece of paper." One of my colleagues, Ms. Iyer proudly introduces herself as "Adv. Iyer", yet most of her work is related to contract management.
normalised: And don't even get me started on the abbreviations. You spend years deciphering what a P-G-D-M or an M-Tech actually means, only to realize it's just a fancy way of saying “I spent a lot of money on a piece of paper.” One of my colleagues, M-S Iyer proudly introduces herself as “Advocate Iyer”, yet most of her work is related to contract management.

unnormalised: The truth is, while these certificates and achievements are undoubtedly important, they're not the be-all and end-all. A fancy degree from IIT Delhi doesn't guarantee happiness or success. Neither does getting 100% in your ICSE exams. It just means you're good at taking tests. So, next time you feel the urge to enroll in another online course just to add another line to your resume, take a deep breath, grab a cup of chai, and ask yourself: Are you doing this for yourself, or for Sharmaji's validation?
normalised: The truth is, while these certificates and achievements are undoubtedly important, they're not the be-all and end-all. A fancy degree from I-I-T Delhi doesn't guarantee happiness or success. Neither does getting one hundred percent in your I-C-S-E exams. It just means you're good at taking tests. So, next time you feel the urge to enroll in another online course just to add another line to your resume, take a deep breath, grab a cup of chai, and ask yourself: Are you doing this for yourself, or for Sharmaji's validation?

unnormalised: Ultimately, it's not about the titles we hold, but the impact we make. And maybe, just maybe, the ability to laugh at ourselves amidst the chaos of the Indian education system. After all, life is too short to be taken seriously, especially when you have "Distinction in Communicative English" printed on your CV. So, go forth, embrace your quirks, and remember: a sense of humour is the most valuable qualification of all.
normalised: Ultimately, it's not about the titles we hold, but the impact we make. And maybe, just maybe, the ability to laugh at ourselves amidst the chaos of the Indian education system. After all, life is too short to be taken seriously, especially when you have “Distinction in Communicative English” printed on your C-V. So, go forth, embrace your quirks, and remember: a sense of humour is the most valuable qualification of all.
